instruction: How were the machine learning models used in the research on using hyperspectral imaging to identify wheat infected with soil-borne mosaic virus?
Output:
In the research on using hyperspectral imaging to identify wheat infected with soil-borne mosaic virus, machine learning models were used to create a classification model. This model was trained using hyperspectral data acquired in a lab setting, specifically scanning leaf samples to investigate spectral differences between healthy and diseased leaves. The model was trained to automatically separate pixels into three classes: symptomatic, non-symptomatic, and healthy. 

The researchers explored the potential of 84 commonly used vegetation indices to find infection. The success rate of the model using the full spectrum was 69.7%. However, by using a subset of only four broad bands, sampled to simulate a data set from a simpler and less costly multispectral camera, the accuracy increased to 71.3%.

Furthermore, the classification models were validated on field data. The classifiers trained on the entire spectrum of the hyperspectral data acquired in the lab setting successfully identified infection in the field with an accuracy of 64.9%. When using a subset of wavelengths to simulate multispectral data, the accuracy dropped by only 3 percentage points to 61.9%. This research demonstrates the potential of using lab scans to train classifiers that can be successfully applied in the field, even when reducing the hyperspectral data to multispectral data.

instruction: Can the classification models trained on hyperspectral data acquired in the lab setting be applied in the field to identify wheat infected with soil-borne mosaic virus with a similar level of accuracy?
Output: Yes, the classification models trained on hyperspectral data acquired in the lab setting can be successfully applied in the field to identify wheat infected with soil-borne mosaic virus with a similar level of accuracy.
